He asked his friend, the wise old owl, for help. The owl took a look at the wheat and said, "Don't worry, Jack. Your wheat just needs a little extra love and care." So, Jack followed the owl's advice and soon his wheat was back to normal. Jack was happy and so was his wheat. The end.

Once upon a time, there was a little girl named Lily. She wanted to go to the park with her mommy and daddy, but they didn't have enough seats in the car. Lily insisted that she could sit on the floor, but her parents said it wasn't safe. 
Finally, her daddy had an idea. He said, "Lily, why don't you sit in my lap? That way we can all go to the park together!" Lily thought this was a great idea and climbed into her daddy's lap. 
When they got to the park, Lily wanted to play on the swings. But she was a little scared because they looked hard. Her mommy said, "Don't worry, Lily. The swings are easy to use. I'll show you how!" And sure enough, after a few tries, Lily was swinging higher than anyone else in the park. 
Lily had so much fun at the park that day, and she was so happy that her parents found an easy way to bring her along. She insisted that they come back again soon, and they all agreed it was a great idea. The end.

Once upon a time, there was a big dog named Max. Max liked to play and run outside with his friends. One day, Max's owner said they were going on a trip and they had to pack their bags. Max helped by putting his favorite toy in the bag.
When they got to their destination, Max saw a nurse who was very nice. She gave him a treat and petted him. Max was happy and alert because he liked the nurse.
At night, Max slept in his own bed and dreamt about playing with his friends again. The next day, they went on a walk and Max saw a squirrel. He barked and ran after it, but his owner told him to come back. Max listened and went back to his owner.
After their walk, they went back to their room and Max helped pack their bags again. He put his toy back in the bag and was ready to go home. Max had a great trip and couldn't wait to play with his friends again. The end.

Once upon a time, there was a little girl named Lily. She had a delicate teacup that she loved to drink her tea from. One day, she accidentally dropped the teacup on the table and it broke into many pieces. Lily was very sad and started to cry.
Her mom asked her, "Why are you crying, Lily?"
"My teacup broke," replied Lily.
"Don't worry, we can fix it," said her mom.
"But how? It's in so many pieces," said Lily.
"We can use glue to put it back together. First, we need to weigh all the pieces to make sure we have everything," explained her mom.
So, they carefully gathered all the broken pieces of the teacup and weighed them. Then, they used glue to put the teacup back together. Lily was so happy to have her teacup back on the table again.

Once upon a time, there was a little boy named Timmy. Timmy loved to have fun and play with his toys. One day, he was playing with his favorite toy car when it suddenly vanished! Timmy looked all over for it but couldn't find it anywhere. 
Feeling sad, Timmy went to his wise grandma for help. She smiled and told him not to worry, that sometimes things just disappear but they can always be found again. She suggested they look for the car together. 
So, Timmy and his grandma searched high and low until finally, they found the car hiding under the couch. Timmy was so happy and grateful to his wise grandma for helping him find his toy car. From then on, he made sure to always keep his toys in a safe place so they wouldn't vanish again.

Once upon a time, there was a little boy named Timmy. Timmy loved to play outside in the sun. One day, Timmy found a shiny coin on the ground. He was so happy and excited to have found it. 
But then, he saw his friend Billy coming towards him. Billy wanted the coin too. Timmy didn't want to give it up, but he knew it was the right thing to do. He yielded the coin to Billy and they both smiled. 
Later that day, Timmy's mom asked him to help with the laundry. She gave him a wet shirt to hang up. Timmy hung it up outside, but it wasn't drying. He was sad and didn't know what to do. But then, he remembered the sun. He put the shirt in the sun and it became dry. Timmy was happy again. The end.

Once upon a time, there was a little girl named Lily. Lily loved to eat grapes, especially the yellow ones. One day, Lily went to the park to play. She saw a little boy who looked sad. Lily went over to him and gave him a big hug. The boy smiled and they became friends. They played together and ate some yummy yellow grapes. From that day on, they were always happy when they saw each other at the park.

Once upon a time, there was a little girl named Lily. One day, Lily and her mommy went for a walk in the park. It was raining outside, so they brought an umbrella to stay dry.
Lily asked her mommy, "Can I hold the umbrella, please?" Her mommy said, "Sure, it's easy to hold. Just make sure it stays over our heads."
Lily held the umbrella and they walked together, enjoying the raindrops falling on the umbrella. Suddenly, they saw a little bird trying to fly in the rain. Lily said, "Oh no, the bird will get wet. Can we help it?" Her mommy said, "Yes, let's hold the umbrella over the bird too."
So they held the umbrella over the bird and it stayed dry. The bird chirped happily and flew away. Lily was so happy that they could help the bird. She said, "Mommy, holding the umbrella is so easy and fun. Let's do it again next time!"

Once upon a time, there was a little boy named Timmy. Timmy loved going to the park with his mom. They would swing and slide and play together.
One day, as they were walking to the park, Timmy saw a big, scary dog. He was scared and wanted to go back home. But his mom told him not to be scared and that they would be safe.
When they got to the park, Timmy saw a big, bouncy castle. He was so excited to bounce on it! His mom told him he could go on it after they played on the swings.
After they finished swinging, Timmy ran to the bouncy castle. He bounced and bounced and had so much fun! He wasn't scared anymore because he knew his mom was there to keep him safe.

Once upon a time, a little girl named Lily was playing in the park. She was looking for her cup because she was thirsty. She searched all over, but she couldn't find it. 
Just then, she saw her friend Tommy walking by. "Tommy, have you seen my cup? I can't find it," she said. 
Tommy looked around and saw a cup on the bench. "Is this your cup, Lily?" he asked. 
Lily ran over and saw that it was her cup. "Yes, that's it! Thank you, Tommy!" she said. She took a sip of her cold water and felt much better. 
From then on, Lily made sure to keep a close eye on her cup so she wouldn't lose it again.

Once upon a time, there was a boy named Timmy. Timmy loved to play with his toys. One day, he decided to throw a ball. He threw it so high, it hit the sheet on his bed! Timmy thought it was so cool. 
Then, he tried to throw a bigger ball. But it was too heavy and not easy to throw. So, Timmy went outside and found some leaves. He threw them up in the air and watched them fall down. It was easy to throw the leaves and it was fun to watch them flutter in the wind. 
After playing for a while, Timmy got tired and went inside to take a nap on his cozy sheet. He dreamed about throwing balls, leaves, and even a sheet up in the air! When he woke up, he was excited to go outside and play again.

Once upon a time, there was a little girl named Lily. She loved going to the beach with her family. Every time they went, she would run to the water and jump over the waves. She enjoyed feeling the water on her toes and the sand in her hands.
One day, they went to the beach in the evening. It was getting dark and the sky was turning black. Lily was a little scared of the dark, but she still wanted to play. She asked her dad if they could go closer to the water. He said yes and they walked towards the waves.
Lily saw the waves crashing against the shore and she thought it was so cool. She loved how the water moved and made a loud sound. She felt happy and safe with her family by her side. Even though it was dark, Lily enjoyed playing at the beach with her family.

Lily was a nosy girl who liked to observe everything. She always asked many questions and wanted to know what other people were doing. One day, she saw a man with a big cap on his head. She wondered what was under his cap and decided to follow him.
The man walked into a store and put his cap on a shelf. Lily sneaked behind him and grabbed his cap. She wanted to see what was inside. But when she lifted the cap, she saw nothing but hair. She felt disappointed and bored.
"Hey, what are you doing with my cap?" the man said, turning around and seeing Lily. He looked angry and scared. "Give it back to me!"
Lily dropped the cap and ran away. She felt sorry and ashamed. She realized that she should not have been so nosy and taken the man's cap. She learned that it was not nice to observe other people's things without asking. She decided to be more respectful and curious in a good way.

Tim and Mia are playing in the garden. They have a big box of toys. They like to dig holes and bury their toys. Then they pretend to be pirates and look for treasure.
"Look, I buried my car here," Tim says, pointing to a mound of dirt. "Can you find it?"
Mia nods and takes a shovel. She starts to dig. She likes to play with Tim. He is her best friend.
Suddenly, a strong wind blows. It makes a loud noise. It shakes the trees and the flowers. It lifts the dirt and the toys. It throws them everywhere.
"Wow, look at the wind!" Tim says, holding his hat. "It is very fast and noisy."
Mia drops her shovel. She is scared of the wind. She does not like it. It is too strong and loud. It makes her toys fly away.
"I don't like the wind," Mia says, running to Tim. "It is very mean and scary."
Tim hugs Mia. He is not scared of the wind. He thinks it is fun and exciting. But he sees that Mia is sad and afraid. He wants to make her feel better.
"Don't worry, Mia," Tim says, smiling. "The wind will go away soon. Then we can find our toys again. They are still here. They are just hiding."
Mia looks at Tim. She sees that he is kind and brave. She feels a little better. She smiles back.
"OK, Tim," Mia says, holding his hand. "Let's wait for the wind to go away. Then we can play again."
They sit down on the grass. They watch the wind blow. They wait for it to be quiet. They are still friends.

Tom and Lily are playing in the park. They like to pretend they are brave hunters. They have sticks that they call spears. They look for animals to hunt.
They see a big dog. It is brown and furry. It has a long tail. It is running and barking. Tom and Lily think it is a lion. They want to hunt it.
They rush after the dog. They hold their spears high. They shout and laugh. They think they are very clever.
But the dog is not a lion. It is a friendly dog. It belongs to a man. The man is walking in the park. He sees Tom and Lily. He is not happy.
He calls the dog. The dog stops running. It goes to the man. The man scolds Tom and Lily. He says they are nosy and rude. He says they should not chase his dog. He says they could hurt the dog or themselves.
Tom and Lily feel sorry. They did not mean to be nosy and rude. They did not know the dog was not a lion. They say sorry to the man and the dog. They put down their spears. They go back to their mom. They learn to be more careful.

Tim and Kim were twins who liked to play in the park. They liked to run, jump, slide and swing. But they did not like to share. They always wanted the same toy, the same snack, the same seat. They always fought and cried.
One day, they saw a big statue in the park. It was a statue of a lion and a mouse. The lion had a thorn in his paw and the mouse was helping him. The twins were curious and went closer. They saw a sign that said: "The Lion and the Mouse. A fable by Aesop. The moral is: A kindness is never wasted."
"What is a fable?" asked Tim.
"What is a moral?" asked Kim.
A lady who was sitting on a bench nearby heard them and smiled. She said: "A fable is a story that teaches a lesson. A moral is the lesson that the story teaches. Do you want me to tell you the story of the lion and the mouse?"
The twins nodded and sat down next to the lady. She told them how the lion was the king of the jungle, but he was also very proud and lazy. He did not care about the other animals and he did not listen to anyone. One day, he was sleeping under a tree when a mouse ran over his nose. The lion woke up and was very angry. He caught the mouse and said: "How dare you disturb me? I will eat you for breakfast!"
The mouse was very scared and said: "Please, Mr. Lion, spare me. I did not mean to bother you. I was just looking for food. If you let me go, I will be grateful and I will help you someday."
The lion laughed and said: "You? Help me? How can a tiny mouse help a mighty lion? You are too weak and small. But I am feeling generous today, so I will let you go. But don't ever come near me again."
The mouse thanked the lion and ran away. The lion went back to sleep.
A few days later, the lion was walking in the forest when he stepped on a sharp thorn. The thorn pierced his paw and made him bleed. The lion roared in pain and tried to pull out the thorn, but he could not reach it. He was in trouble and he needed help.
The mouse heard the lion's roar and recognized his voice. He remembered how the lion had spared his life and he decided to help him. He ran to the lion and said: "Mr. Lion, what is wrong? Can I help you?"
The lion was surprised and ashamed to see the mouse. He said: "Oh, it's you. I have a thorn in my paw and it hurts a lot. But you can't help me. You are too weak and small."
The mouse said: "Don't say that, Mr. Lion. You may be big and strong, but I am smart and brave. Let me see your paw. Maybe I can pull out the thorn."
The lion was doubtful, but he was also desperate. He said: "All right, try it. But be careful. Don't hurt me more."
The mouse climbed on the lion's paw and saw the thorn. He used his teeth and his claws and he pulled out the thorn. The lion felt a relief and thanked the mouse. He said: "You are amazing, little mouse. You have saved me. You have proved that you can help me. I was wrong to laugh at you and to be proud and lazy. I am sorry. Can you forgive me?"
The mouse said: "Of course, I forgive you, Mr. Lion. You have also proved that you can be kind and grateful. I am glad that we are friends. The moral is: A kindness is never wasted."
The twins listened to the story and learned the moral. They looked at each other and said: "We are sorry for fighting and crying. We should be kind and share. We should not be proud and lazy. We should be friends."
The lady smiled and said: "That's right, Tim and Kim. You have learned a valuable lesson. Now, go and play and have fun. And remember: A kindness is never wasted."

Lily was a little girl who liked to play pretend. She had a toy kitchen and a toy tea set. She liked to make tea and cookies for her stuffed animals. She would put them on a tray and carry them to the table. She would say, "Here you are, Mr. Bear. Here you are, Mrs. Bunny. Enjoy your tea and cookies." She would bow and smile.
One day, Lily wanted to try something new. She went to the fridge and found some cheese. She thought cheese would be good with tea and cookies. She put some cheese on the tray and carried it to the table. She said, "Here you are, Mr. Bear. Here you are, Mrs. Bunny. Enjoy your cheese and cookies." She bowed and smiled.
But Mr. Bear and Mrs. Bunny did not like cheese and cookies. They smelled the cheese and made a face. They said, "Yuck! This cheese is disgusting. It is old and moldy. We do not want to eat it. We want to eat fresh and yummy cookies." They pushed the tray away.
Lily was sad and confused. She did not know that cheese could be old and moldy. She thought cheese was always good. She looked at the cheese and saw that it had green spots. She felt sick. She said, "I am sorry, Mr. Bear. I am sorry, Mrs. Bunny. I did not mean to give you disgusting cheese. I thought it was good cheese. I will throw it away and make you new cookies."
She took the tray and went to the trash. She threw away the cheese and washed the tray. She made new cookies and put them on the tray. She carried them to the table. She said, "Here you are, Mr. Bear. Here you are, Mrs. Bunny. Enjoy your new cookies. They are fresh and yummy." She bowed and smiled.
Mr. Bear and Mrs. Bunny were happy and grateful. They smelled the cookies and made a face. They said, "Mmm! These cookies are delicious. They are warm and sweet. We want to eat them. Thank you, Lily. You are a good friend." They pulled the tray closer.
Lily was happy and proud. She had learned something new. She had learned that cheese could be old and moldy. She had learned that old and moldy cheese was disgusting. She had learned that fresh and yummy cookies were delicious. She had learned that her friends liked fresh and yummy cookies. She said, "You are welcome, Mr. Bear. You are welcome, Mrs. Bunny. You are my good friends. Let us have tea and cookies together." She sat down and joined them. They had a nice tea party.

Anna was very happy. Today was her birthday. She had a big cake with candles and a pink dress. She wanted to play with her friends and open her presents. But her friends did not come. They had other things to do. They ignored Anna and her birthday.
Anna was very sad. She did not understand why her friends did not like her. She cried and hugged her teddy bear. She wished she had a real friend who would not ignore her. She looked at her cake and did not want to eat it.
Then she heard a knock on the door. She opened it and saw a big box with a bow. She did not know who sent it. She opened the box and saw a puppy. The puppy was brown and fluffy and had a collar with a tag. The tag said: "Happy birthday, Anna. I am your new friend. My name is Spot."
Anna was very surprised. She had never seen a puppy like this before. It was unusual. But she liked it. She picked up the puppy and hugged it. The puppy licked her face and wagged its tail. Anna smiled and laughed. She forgot about her friends who ignored her. She had a new friend who loved her. She said: "Thank you, Spot. You are the best birthday present ever."

Sara and Tom are playing in the garden. They have a big tub of water and some toys. Sara has a yellow duck and Tom has a blue boat. They splash and laugh and have fun.
"Look, my duck can swim!" Sara says. She makes the duck go up and down in the water.
"My boat can sail!" Tom says. He blows on the boat and makes it move across the tub.
They play for a long time. The sun is hot and the water is cool. They get wet and so do their toys.
"Uh-oh, Mom is calling us!" Sara says. She hears Mom's voice from the house.
"Time to come in, kids! Lunch is ready!" Mom says.
Sara and Tom get out of the tub. They pick up their toys and run to the house.
"Wait, we have to dry our toys!" Tom says. He remembers that water can make toys go bad.
"You're right, Tom. You're very smart!" Sara says. She agrees with Tom.
They find a towel and wipe their toys. They make sure they are not wet anymore.
"Good job, kids! You took good care of your toys!" Mom says. She smiles and hugs them.
They go inside and eat their lunch. They are happy and hungry. They still have their yellow duck and blue boat. They will play with them again later.

Ben was a smart boy who liked to play with his toys. He had a staff that he pretended was a magic wand. He liked to wave it and say funny words. One day, he found a book in his dad's room that had pictures of spells. He wanted to try one.
He opened the book and saw a spell that said "shrink". He thought it would be fun to make things smaller. He pointed his staff at his teddy bear and said the words. The teddy bear became very tiny. Ben was happy. He looked for more things to shrink.
He saw his dad's phone on the table. He pointed his staff at it and said the words. The phone became very tiny too. Ben was happier. He looked for more things to shrink.
He saw his mom's necklace on the dresser. He pointed his staff at it and said the words. The necklace became very tiny as well. Ben was the happiest. He looked for more things to shrink.
He saw his baby sister in her crib. He pointed his staff at her and said the words. The baby sister became very tiny, smaller than his thumb. Ben was not happy. He was scared. He tried to pick her up, but she was too small. He dropped her on the floor. He heard a loud cry.
His mom and dad came running. They saw the tiny baby sister on the floor. They saw the tiny phone, the tiny necklace, and the tiny teddy bear. They saw the book and the staff. They were very angry and very sad. They yelled at Ben and took him to his room. They called the doctor and the police. They did not know how to make the baby sister big again.
Ben was not smart. He was very sorry. He wished he never played with the staff. He wished he never said the words. He wished he never shrunk his baby sister. He cried and cried. He had a bad ending.

Lila was a modest girl who liked to help her mom and dad. She did not ask for many toys or treats. She was happy with her books and dolls. One day, she saw a big train at the park. It had many cars and a loud whistle. Lila wanted to ride the train, but she was afraid.
She asked her mom, "Can I ride the train, please?"
Her mom said, "Yes, you can, but you have to try. It is not scary, it is fun. You can hold my hand if you want."
Lila nodded and followed her mom to the train. She saw a long line of people waiting to get on. She saw some kids who were excited and some who were nervous. She felt her heart beat fast.
When it was their turn, her mom helped her climb on the train. She sat on a seat near the rail. She held her mom's hand tight. She heard the whistle blow and the train start to move. She closed her eyes.
Her mom said, "Look, Lila, look at the trees and the flowers and the animals. They are so pretty. The train is going fast, but it is safe. You are brave, Lila, you are trying something new."
Lila opened her eyes and looked around. She saw the green grass and the blue sky and the yellow sun. She saw the birds and the squirrels and the rabbits. She saw the other kids smiling and waving. She felt the wind in her hair and the sun on her face. She felt her mom's hand warm and soft. She felt a smile on her lips.
She said, "Mom, I like the train. It is fun. Thank you for helping me try."
Her mom said, "You are welcome, Lila. I am proud of you. You learned that trying new things can be good. You are a modest and brave girl, Lila, and I love you."
They hugged and enjoyed the rest of the ride. Lila was happy. She had tried something new and she had liked it. She had learned a lesson. She had made her mom proud.

Lila and Ben were friends who liked to play with toys. One day, they decided to trade some of their toys and see what they could get. Lila had a doll, a ball, and a car. Ben had a truck, a teddy, and a book.
"I want your car, Lila. It is fast and shiny. Can I trade you my truck for it?" Ben asked.
"OK, Ben. I like your truck. It is big and strong. Let's trade," Lila said. She gave Ben her car and took his truck.
They played with their new toys for a while, but then Lila saw Ben's teddy. It was soft and cuddly. She wanted it too.
"Ben, can I trade you my ball for your teddy? I think your teddy is very cute. Please?" Lila asked.
"OK, Lila. I like your ball. It is round and bouncy. Let's trade," Ben said. He gave Lila his teddy and took her ball.
They played with their new toys for a while, but then Lila saw Ben's book. It had pictures and words. She wanted it too.
"Ben, can I trade you my doll for your book? I think your book is very interesting. Please?" Lila asked.
"OK, Lila. I like your doll. It is pretty and has a dress. Let's trade," Ben said. He gave Lila his book and took her doll.
They played with their new toys for a while, but then Ben realized he had nothing left. He had traded all his toys to Lila. He felt sad and angry.
"Lila, you are not fair. You took all my toys. I want them back. Give them to me now!" Ben shouted.
"No, Ben. They are mine now. I traded them with you. You agreed. Go away!" Lila shouted back.
They started to fight and pull each other's hair. They were not friends anymore. They were enemies.
A teacher saw them and came to stop them. She was not happy. She scolded them and took away all their toys. She said they had to learn to share and be nice.
Lila and Ben felt sorry and ashamed. They had no toys and no friends. They had made a bad trade. They wished they had never traded their toys. They wished they had played with them together and had fun. But it was too late. They had ruined their day.

Lily and Ben were twins, but they were very different. Lily liked to play with dolls and draw pictures. Ben liked to play with cars and build blocks. One day, they had to share a tray of cookies that their mom made for them.
"Let's pray first," Lily said. She closed her eyes and folded her hands. "Thank you, God, for the cookies and for mom and dad and for Ben."
Ben rolled his eyes. He did not like to pray. He wanted to eat the cookies right away. He opened his eyes and reached for the tray.
"Hey, stop!" Lily said. She opened her eyes and saw Ben grabbing a cookie. "That's not fair! You have to pray first!"
"No, I don't!" Ben said. He bit the cookie and smiled. "Mmm, yummy!"
Lily felt angry and sad. She wanted to share the cookies with Ben, but he did not care. She started to cry.
Mom heard Lily crying and came to see what was wrong. She saw the tray of cookies and Ben's crumbs on his mouth.
"What happened here?" Mom asked.
"Lily wanted me to pray, but I didn't want to," Ben said.
"Lily, why did you want Ben to pray?" Mom asked.
"Because it's good to thank God for what we have," Lily said.
Mom nodded. She understood how Lily felt. She also understood how Ben felt. She loved them both, even though they were different.
"Ben, I'm glad you like the cookies, but you should respect Lily's choice to pray. Praying is a way of talking to God and showing gratitude. You don't have to pray if you don't want to, but you should wait for Lily to finish before you take a cookie," Mom said.
"Sorry, Lily," Ben said. He felt a little sorry for making Lily cry.
"Lily, I'm proud of you for praying, but you should respect Ben's choice not to pray. Not everyone believes in God or prays the same way. You can pray for yourself and for Ben, but you can't force him to pray with you," Mom said.
"Sorry, Ben," Lily said. She felt a little sorry for being angry at Ben.
Mom smiled. She hugged them both and gave them each another cookie.
"Can we still play together?" Ben asked.
"Of course we can," Lily said.
They ate their cookies and then played with their toys. They were different, but they were still twins. And they still loved each other.

Anna likes to play with her dolls. She has many dolls, but her favorite is Lily. Lily has long hair and a pink dress. Anna likes to brush Lily's hair and make her talk.
One day, Anna is playing with Lily in her room. She makes Lily say hello to her other dolls and have a tea party. She is having fun, but she feels a little lonely. She wishes she had a friend to play with.
She hears a knock on the door. She wonders who it is. She puts Lily down and goes to the door. She opens it and sees a boy. He is holding a toy car. He has short hair and a blue shirt. He smiles at her.
"Hi, I'm Ben," he says. "I live next door. Can I play with you?"
Anna notices his voice. It is gentle and friendly. She feels happy. She likes his voice. She thinks he might be a good friend.
"Hi, I'm Anna," she says. "This is Lily. She is my doll. Do you want to play with her?"
Ben nods. He likes dolls too. He has a sister who has dolls. He follows Anna to her room. He sees her other dolls and her tea set. He thinks they look nice.
They sit on the floor and play with the dolls. They make them talk and drink tea. They laugh and have fun. They are not lonely anymore. They are happy. They have found a new friend.

Lily and Tom are friends. They like to play and learn together. One day, they visit a farm with their class. They see cows, pigs, chickens and sheep. They are happy and curious.
"Look, Tom, this is where cheese comes from!" Lily says, pointing to a big machine that squeezes milk from the cows.
"Wow, cheese is yummy! I want to try some!" Tom says, licking his lips.
They follow the farmer, who shows them how he makes cheese. He cuts, cooks, and shapes the milk into blocks of cheese. He puts some cheese in a basket and gives it to the teacher.
"Thank you, farmer, for the cheese. It is very kind of you," the teacher says.
"You're welcome, teacher. I hope you enjoy it. But be careful, some cheese is very old and strong. It can make your mouth feel funny," the farmer says.
The teacher shares the cheese with the class. They all take a small piece and taste it. Some cheese is soft and mild, some cheese is hard and sharp. Lily and Tom like the cheese. They think it is delicious.
But some children do not like the cheese. They make faces and spit it out. They say the cheese is bad and stinky. They are rude and ungrateful.
"Yuck, this cheese is gross! I don't want it!" one child says, throwing his piece on the ground.
"Me neither! This cheese is nasty! I want candy!" another child says, tossing his piece in the air.
The farmer sees the children being wasteful and disrespectful. He is sad and angry. He scolds the children for their bad manners.
"Shame on you, children, for wasting good cheese. Cheese is a gift from the cows and the land. You should be thankful and polite. If you don't like the cheese, you can say no thank you, but you don't have to throw it away or insult it. That is not smart or nice," the farmer says.
The children feel ashamed and sorry. They apologize to the farmer and the teacher. They promise to be more careful and respectful next time.
Lily and Tom are smart and nice. They thank the farmer again for the cheese. They ask him more questions about the farm and the animals. They learn a lot and have fun.
The moral of the story is: Be thankful and polite for what you have. Don't waste or insult food. Be smart and nice.

Ben and Lily are twins. They like to play and have fun. One day, they find a big box in the garage. They think it is a good place to hide and scare Mom.
"Let's make a joke on Mom," Ben says. "You hide in the box and I will call her. When she comes, you spring out and say boo!"
"OK, that sounds fun," Lily says. She gets in the box and closes the lid. Ben runs to the kitchen and says, "Mom, Mom, come and see what I found!"
Mom follows Ben to the garage. She sees the big box and wonders what is inside. She opens the lid and Lily springs out and says, "Boo!"
Mom is very surprised and jumps back. She laughs and says, "Oh, you got me! What a funny joke!"
But then she sees that Lily has a hurt face. She has a cut on her cheek from the box. Mom says, "Oh, no, Lily, are you OK? Let me see your face."
Lily starts to cry and says, "It hurts, Mom, it hurts!"
Mom hugs Lily and says, "I'm sorry, sweetie, it was an accident. Let's go and get a band-aid and some ice. You will be fine."
Ben feels bad and says, "I'm sorry, too, Lily. I didn't mean to hurt you. It was supposed to be a fun joke."
Lily says, "It's OK, Ben. I still love you. But next time, let's find a softer box."

Tom and Lily liked to play in the park. They had a big flag that they made with their mom. The flag had red and blue and yellow and green. They liked to wave the flag and run with it.
One day, a big dog came to the park. The dog was crazy. He barked and jumped and chased the kids. Tom and Lily were scared. They ran away from the dog, but the dog ran faster. He caught the flag and bit it. He tore the flag with his teeth. The flag was broken.
Tom and Lily were sad. They cried and hugged each other. They loved their flag. They wanted to fix it. They saw a man who worked in the park. He had a tool box and a hat. He looked nice.
"Excuse me, sir," Tom said. "Can you help us? The dog broke our flag. Can you repair it?"
The man smiled. He took the flag and looked at it. He said, "I can try. I have some tape and some scissors and some glue. Maybe I can make your flag look good again."
He opened his tool box and took out some things. He cut and taped and glued the flag. He worked hard and fast. He gave the flag back to Tom and Lily. The flag looked almost like new. It had red and blue and yellow and green.
Tom and Lily were happy. They thanked the man and gave him a hug. They waved their flag and ran with it. They played in the park and had fun. The dog was gone. The flag was repaired. The end.

Tim likes to jog with his dad. They jog in the park and see many things. They see birds, flowers, dogs and people. Tim likes to say hello to everyone. He is a compassionate boy.
One day, they jog near a big drain. The drain has a metal cover with holes. Tim is curious and looks inside. He sees water and mud. He wants to touch it, but his dad says no. He says the drain is dirty and dangerous.
Tim listens to his dad, but he sees something shiny in the drain. It is a coin. He thinks it is a treasure. He reaches for it, but his dad stops him. He says the coin is not worth it. He says he has a better treasure for him.
He takes out a small box from his pocket and gives it to Tim. Tim opens it and sees a compass. It is a gift from his dad. He says the compass can help him find his way. He says he loves him very much.
Tim hugs his dad and says thank you. He is very happy. He puts the compass in his pocket and holds his dad's hand. They jog away from the drain and continue their adventure.

Tommy was very tired. He wanted to sleep in his bed. But his bed had no pillow. He looked for his pillow everywhere. He could not find it.
He went to his mom. He said, "Mom, I need my pillow. Where is my pillow?" Mom was busy. She said, "I don't know, Tommy. Maybe you left it in the living room. Go and look there."
Tommy went to the living room. He saw a big pillow on the couch. He thought it was his pillow. He grabbed it and ran to his bed. He put it under his head. But it was not his pillow. It was an empty pillow case. It had no stuffing inside. It was flat and soft.
Tommy felt sad. He did not like the empty pillow case. He wanted his pillow. He went back to his mom. He said, "Mom, this is not my pillow. This is an empty pillow case. It has no stuffing. It is flat and soft. I don't like it. Please give me my pillow."
Mom looked at the empty pillow case. She said, "Oh, Tommy, I'm sorry. This is not your pillow. This is the pillow case I washed today. I forgot to put the stuffing back in. Your pillow is in the dryer. Wait a minute. I will get it for you."
Mom went to the dryer. She took out Tommy's pillow. It was warm and fluffy. She gave it to Tommy. Tommy hugged his pillow. He said, "Thank you, Mom. This is my pillow. I love it. It is warm and fluffy. I like it." He went to his bed. He put his pillow under his head. He closed his eyes. He fell asleep. He had a good dream.

Lily loved to carry her luxury doll everywhere. It was big and soft and had a shiny dress and a hat with a feather. Lily thought her doll was the best thing in the world and she did not want to share it with anyone.
One day, Lily went to the park with her mom and her doll. She saw some other kids playing with balls and trucks and bikes. She did not want to play with them. She only wanted to play with her doll. She hugged her doll and said, "You are my only friend. You are better than all the other toys."
But then, a big dog came running to the park. It saw Lily's doll and thought it was a toy too. It ran towards Lily and grabbed her doll with its mouth. It shook the doll and tore the dress and the hat. It made a big mess.
Lily was very scared and sad. She cried and cried. She wanted her doll back. She tried to get the dog to let go, but it was too strong and fast. It ran away with the doll.
Lily's mom came to comfort her. She said, "I'm sorry, Lily. That was a bad dog. It did not know that your doll was not a toy. But maybe you can learn something from this. Maybe you can be more kind and friendly to the other kids and their toys. Maybe you can share and play with them. Maybe you can make some new friends. That would make you happier than having a luxury doll."
Lily thought about what her mom said. She felt embarrassed for being so selfish and rude. She realized that her doll was not the best thing in the world. She decided to try to be more nice and open. She wiped her tears and said, "You are right, mom. I'm sorry. Can we go and play with the other kids?"
Her mom smiled and said, "Of course, Lily. Let's go and have some fun." They walked to the playground and Lily saw a girl with a ball. She said, "Hi, I'm Lily. Can I play with you?" The girl smiled and said, "Sure, I'm Anna. This is my ball. Do you want to catch it?" Lily nodded and said, "Yes, please. That sounds fun." They threw and caught the ball and laughed and talked. Lily felt happy and forgot about her doll. She made a new friend.

Lily liked to play with her friends at the park. They liked to swing, slide and run. One day, they saw a new thing at the park. It was a long line of stones. The stones were different colors and shapes. Some were big and some were small. Some were round and some were sharp.
Lily's friends wanted to walk on the line of stones. They said it looked fun and harmless. They said it was like a bridge or a train. Lily was not sure. She thought the line of stones looked hard and dangerous. She thought it could hurt her feet or make her fall. She did not trust the line of stones.
Lily's friends went to the line of stones. They started to walk on it, one by one. They laughed and cheered. They said it was easy and fun. They told Lily to join them. They said she was scared and silly. Lily felt sad and lonely. She wanted to play with her friends, but she did not want to walk on the line of stones.
Then, something bad happened. One of Lily's friends stepped on a sharp stone. He cried out in pain. He had a cut on his foot. It was bleeding. He could not walk. He needed help. The other friends stopped walking on the line of stones. They ran to him. They were sorry and scared. They did not know what to do.
Lily saw what happened. She felt sorry for her friend. She also felt glad that she did not walk on the line of stones. She knew she was right to not trust it. She ran to the bench where her mom was sitting. She told her mom what happened. Her mom was kind and smart. She had a band-aid and a hug. She went to help Lily's friend. She cleaned his wound and put the band-aid on it. She told him it would be okay. She told him to be careful next time. She told him to trust his feelings.
Lily's friend felt better. He thanked Lily's mom. He also thanked Lily. He said he was sorry for calling her scared and silly. He said he was wrong to walk on the line of stones. He said it was not fun and harmless. He said it was hard and dangerous. He said he learned a lesson. He said he would trust Lily more. Lily smiled. She forgave her friend. She was happy that he was okay. She was also happy that he trusted her. She hugged him and her mom. They all went back to the park. They played on the swing, the slide and the grass. They had fun and they were safe. They were good friends.

Tom and Lily are friends. They like to play in the park. One day, they see a big bus. The bus has many people. The people are on a tour. They want to see the park and the animals.
Tom and Lily are curious. They want to see the bus and the people. They run to the bus. They see a man. The man is the driver. He has a hat and a microphone. He talks to the people. He tells them about the park and the animals.
The driver sees Tom and Lily. He smiles. He asks them if they want to join the tour. Tom and Lily are happy. They nod. The driver lets them on the bus. He gives them a seat. He provides them with snacks and water. He tells them to enjoy the tour.
The bus starts to move. It goes around the park. It stops at different places. The driver points to the animals. He says their names and what they do. Tom and Lily see many animals. They see birds, squirrels, rabbits, ducks, and dogs. They like the animals. They think they are cute and funny.
But then, they see a big animal. It is brown and hairy. It has horns and a long nose. It makes a loud noise. It is a bison. Tom and Lily are scared. They think the bison is ugly and mean. They hide behind the seat. They do not want to see the bison. They want the bus to go away.
The driver sees Tom and Lily. He laughs. He tells them not to be afraid. He says the bison is not ugly and mean. He says the bison is friendly and gentle. He says the bison is part of the park and the tour. He says the bison is beautiful and special.
Tom and Lily are not sure. They peek at the bison. They see the bison is calm and quiet. They see the bison is eating grass and flowers. They see the bison is not alone. They see other bison with the bison. They see baby bison with their moms and dads.
Tom and Lily are surprised. They think the bison is not so ugly and mean. They think the bison is kind of cute and nice. They think the bison is like a big cow. They smile. They like the bison. They like the tour. They thank the driver. They have fun.

Sam and Lily are friends. They like to play at the park. They see a big slide. They want to go on the slide.
"Let's go on the slide!" Sam says.
"OK!" Lily says.
They run to the slide. They take turns to go down. They have fun. They laugh and shout.
But the slide is dirty. It has mud and leaves on it. Sam and Lily do not see the dirt. They go down the slide again and again.
Soon, they are dirty too. They have mud and leaves on their clothes and hair. They do not care. They are happy.
But then, they see their moms. Their moms are not happy. They are angry.
"Look at you! You are so dirty!" Sam's mom says.
"What have you done? You need a bath!" Lily's mom says.
Sam and Lily look at each other. They are sad. They do not want to leave the slide. They do not want to take a bath.
"Can we play more?" Sam asks.
"Please?" Lily asks.
But their moms say no. They say they have to go home. They say they have to get clean.
Sam and Lily sigh. They say bye to the slide. They say bye to each other. They follow their moms.
They hope they can play on the slide again. They hope they can get dirty again. They hope their moms will not be angry again.

Sara and Ben are twins. They like to play in the big building where Mom works. Mom says they can go up and down the elevator, but they have to stay with her. One day, Sara and Ben are bored. They want to see what is on the top floor. They sneak into the elevator when Mom is not looking. They push the button with the highest number.
The elevator goes up and up and up. Sara and Ben are excited. They wonder what they will find on the top floor. Maybe there are toys or candy or animals. But when the elevator stops, the door does not open. Sara and Ben are stuck. They push the buttons again and again, but nothing happens. They call for Mom, but no one hears them. They start to feel scared.
The elevator is dark and cold. Sara and Ben shiver. They hug each other and wish Mom would come. They hear a loud noise. It sounds like thunder. The elevator shakes and rattles. Sara and Ben scream. They think the elevator will fall. They cry and pray for help.
After a long time, the noise stops. The elevator door opens. Sara and Ben see Mom and a man in a uniform. Mom is angry and worried. She hugs Sara and Ben and scolds them for running away. The man in the uniform says the elevator was broken by a storm. He says he fixed it and he is sorry for the trouble. Sara and Ben say they are sorry too. They promise to never sneak into the elevator again. They are happy to see Mom and the light. They are happy to be safe.

Tom and Lily liked to play with blocks. They had many blocks of different colors and shapes. They could create anything they wanted with their blocks. One day, they decided to create a nation with their blocks.
They used purple blocks to make a big castle. The castle was the home of the king and the queen of their nation. They used yellow blocks to make a wall around the castle. The wall was to keep the nation safe from bad people. They used green blocks to make fields and trees. The fields and trees were for the animals and the food of their nation. They used blue blocks to make a river and a lake. The river and the lake were for the water and the fish of their nation.
Tom and Lily were very proud of their nation. They gave their nation a name. They called it Purple Land. They made a flag with a purple star on it. They put the flag on top of the castle. They pretended to be the king and the queen of Purple Land. They made rules and laws for their nation. They had fun and played with their blocks. They loved their nation. They loved Purple Land.

Ben liked to create things with his crayons and paper. He drew cars, houses, animals and flowers. One day, he wanted to create something new. He looked out of the window and saw a green caterpillar on a leaf. He thought it was very interesting.
He took a green crayon and a yellow crayon and started to draw a long line with bumps on his paper. He added a small circle for the head and two dots for the eyes. He smiled and said, "This is my caterpillar. He is my friend."
He showed his drawing to his mom, who was in the kitchen. She looked at it and said, "That's a very nice caterpillar, Ben. What is his name?"
Ben thought for a moment and said, "His name is Bob. He likes to eat leaves and he is very normal."
Mom nodded and said, "That's a good name for a caterpillar. Do you want to hang your drawing on the fridge?"
Ben nodded and said, "Yes, please. I want everyone to see Bob. He is very special to me."
Mom helped Ben to hang his drawing on the fridge with a magnet. She gave him a hug and said, "You are very creative, Ben. I'm proud of you."
Ben hugged her back and said, "Thank you, Mom. I love you."
They went to the living room and read a book about caterpillars and butterflies. Ben learned that Bob would one day change into a beautiful butterfly. He wondered what color Bob would be. He decided to create more drawings of Bob and his friends. He was very happy.

Ben and Lily were twins who liked to play outside. They ran, jumped, climbed and got very dirty. When it was time to go home, their mom said, "You need to bathe before dinner. You are very dirty and smelly."
Ben and Lily did not want to bathe. They liked being dirty and smelly. They said, "No, mom, we do not want to bathe. We want to play more."
Mom said, "You have to bathe, or you will not get any dessert. Now go to the bathroom and I will help you."
Ben and Lily ran to the bathroom, but they did not want to bathe. They had a plan. They hid behind the shower curtain and waited for mom. They thought mom would not find them.
Mom came to the bathroom and saw the empty bathtub. She said, "Where are you, Ben and Lily? I know you are here. I will search for you."
Mom looked under the sink, behind the door, in the cabinet, but she did not find them. She said, "You are very tough to find. But I will not give up. I will find you and make you bathe."
Mom pulled the shower curtain and saw Ben and Lily. They giggled and said, "You found us, mom. You are very smart."
Mom said, "Yes, I found you. And now you have to bathe. Come on, it will be fun. I will put bubbles and toys in the water. And then you will be clean and sweet."
Ben and Lily agreed to bathe. They got in the bathtub and played with the bubbles and toys. Mom washed their hair and body. They splashed and laughed. They said, "We like to bathe, mom. It is fun."
Mom said, "I am glad you like to bathe. You are very good twins. Now let's dry off and go to dinner. And then you will get dessert."
Ben and Lily said, "Yay, dessert. We love you, mom."
Mom said, "I love you, too, Ben and Lily. You are my favorite twins."

Anna and Ben are twins. They like to sing and dance. Today, they have a show at school. They are very happy and excited.
They wear red and blue costumes. They hold hands and walk to the stage. They see many people in the seats. They see their mom and dad. They smile and wave to them.
The music starts. Anna and Ben sing a song. They sing loud and clear. They move their feet and arms. They have fun. The people clap and cheer.
The music stops. Anna and Ben bow to the people. They say, "Thank you for coming!" They run to their mom and dad. They hug and kiss them.
Mom and dad say, "You did great! We are very proud of you!" They give them flowers and balloons. Anna and Ben feel very happy. They have a wide grin on their faces. They wave to their friends and teachers. They say, "Bye-bye! See you soon!"

Lily was a playful girl who liked to run and jump and laugh. She had a big brother, Tom, who was not so playful. He liked to read and write and draw. He had a lot of books and papers and pencils in his room.
One day, Lily was bored and wanted to play with Tom. But Tom was busy doing his homework. He told Lily to go away and leave him alone. Lily was sad and angry. She decided to make Tom play with her. She went to the kitchen and found an iron. She knew that an iron was hot and could make things flat.
She ran to Tom's room with the iron. She saw Tom's books and papers and pencils on his desk. She thought they looked funny and messy. She wanted to make them flat and neat. She plugged the iron in the wall and turned it on. She did not know that an iron could also make things burn.
She put the iron on Tom's books and papers and pencils. She smiled and laughed. She thought Tom would be happy to see his things flat and neat. But Tom was not happy. He was very angry and scared. He saw the iron and the smoke and the fire. He screamed and ran to the kitchen. He got a bucket of water and threw it on the fire. He put out the fire and saved his things.
He looked at Lily and his eyes were cold and hard. He said, "Lily, you are very naughty and stupid. You could have burned the house and hurt yourself and me. You are in big trouble. I will punish you for what you did. You will not play or laugh or have fun for a long time. You will stay in your room and be quiet and sorry."
Lily was very sorry and scared. She cried and begged Tom to forgive her. She said, "Tom, I am sorry. I did not mean to make a fire. I just wanted to play with you. Please do not punish me. Please be nice to me. Please be my brother."
But Tom did not listen. He grabbed Lily and dragged her to her room. He locked the door and took the key. He said, "Lily, you will stay here until I say so. You will learn your lesson. You will never touch my things or the iron again. You will never bother me again. You will be a good girl or else."
Lily was alone and sad and afraid. She did not have anyone to play with or talk to. She did not have any toys or books or pictures. She only had the iron and the fire and the smoke in her mind. She wished she had never seen the iron. She wished she had never made Tom angry. She wished she had been a good girl. She wished she had a brother who loved her.

Lily and Tom are friends. They like to play with blocks. They have many blocks of different colors and shapes. They can make houses, cars, animals and more.
One day, they want to make a big tower with all the blocks. They start to put the blocks on top of each other. They are very careful and clever. They want the tower to be tall and strong.
But then, Max comes. Max is not nice. He likes to break things. He sees the tower and he wants to knock it down. He runs to the tower and pushes it with his hand.
"Stop!" Lily and Tom shout. "Please, don't do that! We worked hard to make the tower. It is our tower. Go away!"
But Max does not listen. He laughs and pushes the tower again. The tower falls down. The blocks scatter everywhere. Lily and Tom are sad and angry. They cry.
"Why are you so mean, Max?" Lily asks. "Why can't you play nice with us?"
Max shrugs. He does not care. He looks for something else to break.
Lily and Tom pick up the blocks. They hug each other. They decide to make another tower. But this time, they move to a different place, where Max can't see them. They are still clever and careful. They hope Max will learn to be nice someday.

Lily and Ben are friends. They like to play at the farm. The farm has many animals. Lily and Ben like to pet the animals. They are soft and nice.
One day, Lily and Ben see a goat. The goat is white and brown. It has horns and a beard. The goat is on a hill. Lily and Ben want to pet the goat. They run to the hill.
But the goat is not happy. The goat does not like strangers. The goat sees Lily and Ben. The goat makes a loud sound. Baa! Baa! The goat runs to Lily and Ben. The goat wants to chase them away.
Lily and Ben are scared. They do not want to be hurt by the goat. They look for a place to hide. They see a pond. The pond has water and fish. Lily and Ben have an idea. They dive into the pond.
The goat is surprised. The goat does not like water. The goat stops at the edge of the pond. The goat looks at Lily and Ben. Lily and Ben are safe in the pond. They splash and laugh. The goat makes a sad sound. Maa! Maa! The goat goes back to the hill.
Lily and Ben are happy. They have fun in the pond. They are not afraid of the goat. They are brave and smart. They are good friends.

Mia and Ben were playing with clay. They liked to make different shapes and colors. Mia made a snake with green clay. She twisted it and made it long and curly. Ben made a ball with yellow clay. He rolled it and made it round and smooth.
"Look at my snake!" Mia said. "It can hiss and bite!"
"Look at my ball!" Ben said. "It can bounce and roll!"
They showed each other their clay creations. They were proud of them.
But then, a big boy came. He was older and taller than Mia and Ben. He was ignorant. He did not know how to play nicely. He saw the clay and wanted to take it.
"Give me your clay!" he said. "I want to make something better!"
He grabbed Mia's snake and Ben's ball. He smashed them together. He made a mess. He laughed.
Mia and Ben were sad and angry. They did not like the big boy. He was mean and rude.
"Hey, stop that!" Mia said. "That's our clay!"
"Go away!" Ben said. "You're not nice!"
But the big boy did not listen. He kept playing with the clay. He did not care about Mia and Ben.
Mia and Ben ran to their teacher. They told her what happened. The teacher was kind and fair. She went to the big boy. She scolded him. She made him give back the clay. She made him say sorry.
Mia and Ben got their clay back. They tried to fix their snake and ball. They thanked their teacher. They hugged each other.
They learned a lesson. They learned to share and respect. They learned to stand up for themselves. They learned to ignore ignorant people. They learned to be happy.

Lila and Tom were twins who liked to play outside. One day, they found a big pile of pebbles near the river. They decided to make a game with them. They each took some pebbles and threw them into the water, trying to make the biggest splash.
"Look, I found a shiny pebble!" Lila said, holding up a smooth, black stone. "It looks like a star!"
"Let me see!" Tom said, reaching for the pebble. "Maybe it has magic!"
Lila did not want to share. She hid the pebble in her pocket and ran away. Tom was angry and chased her. They ran and ran, until they came to a dark forest.
"Stop, Lila!" Tom shouted. "Give me the pebble!"
"No, it's mine!" Lila shouted back. "Go away!"
They did not see the big bear that was sleeping behind a tree. The bear heard their noise and woke up. He was hungry and angry. He saw the two children and roared.
Lila and Tom were scared. They tried to run away, but the bear was faster. He caught them and ate them. The pebble fell out of Lila's pocket and rolled into the river. It was gone.
The moral of the story is: Do not be greedy and selfish. Share with your brother or sister. And do not disturb a sleeping bear.

Lily was very hungry. She wanted to eat something yummy. She saw a big tray on the table. The tray had many things on it. There were cookies, cakes, fruits, and cheese. Lily thought the tray looked amazing.
She ran to the table and grabbed a cookie. She took a big bite. It was sweet and crunchy. She smiled and reached for a cake. She took another bite. It was soft and creamy. She was very happy and reached for a fruit.
But then she heard a loud voice. It was Mom. Mom was angry. She said, "Lily, what are you doing? That tray is not for you. That tray is for the guests. You are very naughty. You did not ask. You did not accept what I gave you for lunch. You spoiled the tray. Now go to your room. No more treats for you today."
Lily felt very sad. She dropped the fruit and started to cry. She did not understand. She thought the tray was for everyone. She thought Mom would be proud of her for trying new things. She did not mean to be naughty. She just wanted to eat something amazing.
She ran to her room and slammed the door. She hugged her teddy bear and sobbed. She wished she had accepted what Mom gave her for lunch. She wished she had not seen the tray. She wished she had not been so hungry. She wished Mom would forgive her. She wished she could have another cookie.

Ben and Lily wanted to play in the garden. They saw some big jars on the table. The jars had labels on them. The labels said: "Do not touch. Dangerous."
"What are these?" Ben asked.
"I don't know. Maybe they are for Mom's plants," Lily said.
"Let's open them and see," Ben said. He reached for a jar.
"No, Ben, stop! The label says 'do not touch'. It is dangerous. It might hurt you," Lily said.
"But I want to see. Maybe it is something fun," Ben said. He did not listen to Lily. He opened the jar.
Suddenly, a loud noise came from the jar. Smoke and bubbles came out. Ben and Lily screamed. They ran away from the table.
Mom heard the noise and came to the garden. She saw the mess on the table. She saw Ben and Lily hiding behind a bush.
"What happened here?" Mom asked.
"Ben opened a jar. It made a big boom. It was scary," Lily said.
"Ben, why did you open the jar? Didn't you see the label? It was dangerous. I was preparing a science experiment for your big brother. You could have hurt yourself or Lily," Mom said.
"I'm sorry, Mom. I was curious. I wanted to see what was inside," Ben said.
"Curiosity is good, but you have to be careful. You have to follow the rules. You have to respect the labels. They are there to protect you. Do you understand?" Mom said.
"Yes, Mom. I understand. I won't do it again," Ben said.
"Good. Now, let's clean up this mess. And then, we can do something fun and safe together. How about we make some cookies?" Mom said.
"Yay! Cookies!" Ben and Lily said.
They hugged Mom and went to the kitchen. They learned their lesson. They never touched the jars again.

Lily and Sam were playing in the snow. They wanted to make an igloo, like the ones they saw in a book. They rolled big balls of snow and stacked them together. They left a hole for the door.
"Look, we made an igloo!" Lily said. "Let's go inside and pretend we live here."
They crawled inside the igloo and sat on the floor. They felt cozy and warm. They pretended they had a fire and a pot of soup.
"What kind of soup do you want?" Sam asked.
"I want spicy soup, like the one Mommy makes," Lily said.
"Me too," Sam said. "But we don't have any spicy things here. Only snow."
Sam had an idea. He crawled out of the igloo and looked around. He saw a red pepper in the garden. It was frozen, but still bright and shiny. He picked it up and brought it back to the igloo.
"Look, I found something spicy!" he said. "Let's put it in our soup."
He broke the pepper in half and gave one piece to Lily. They both bit into it and smiled.
"Mmm, spicy!" Lily said.
But then, they felt a burning sensation in their mouths. They gasped and coughed. Their eyes watered and their noses ran. They spit out the pepper and ran out of the igloo.
"Ow, ow, ow!" they cried. "That was too spicy!"
They ran to the house and asked Mommy for some water and milk. Mommy hugged them and gave them a glass each. She asked them what happened.
"We ate a spicy pepper from the garden," Lily said.
"We wanted to make spicy soup in our igloo," Sam said.
Mommy smiled and shook her head. She said, "Next time, be careful what you put in your soup. And don't eat frozen peppers. They are not good for you."
Lily and Sam nodded and drank their water and milk. They felt better and said sorry to Mommy. They learned their lesson. They decided to make a different kind of soup next time. Maybe carrot soup, or chicken soup, or tomato soup. But not spicy soup. Never again.

Sam and Mia were playing with their toys in the living room. Sam had a big truck with four wheels and a horn. Mia had a doll with a dress and a hat. They were having fun making noises and moving their toys around.
Then, Sam saw a shiny knob on the shelf. He liked shiny things and wanted to see what it was. He put down his truck and climbed on the couch to reach the knob. He took it in his hand and turned it. It made a click sound.
"Look, Mia, I found a knob!" Sam said. "It can make sounds. Do you want to play with it?"
Mia looked at the knob and shook her head. She did not like the knob. It was not pretty or soft like her doll. She wanted to keep playing with her doll.
"No, thank you, Sam," Mia said. "I don't want the knob. You can have it."
Sam felt sad. He wanted to share the knob with Mia. He thought it was a fun toy. He had an idea. He decided to sell the knob to Mia.
"Mia, do you want to buy the knob?" Sam asked. "I will sell it to you for one cookie. It is a good deal. The knob can make sounds and it is shiny."
Mia looked at Sam and felt confused. She did not understand what he meant by sell and buy. She liked cookies, but she did not want the knob. She thought Sam was being silly.
"Sam, I don't want to buy the knob," Mia said. "I don't have any cookies. And I don't like the knob. I like my doll. Why don't you play with your truck? It is a nice truck."
Sam felt more sad. He did not want to play with his truck. He wanted to play with the knob. He did not know why Mia did not like the knob. He thought it was a great toy. He put the knob back on the shelf and climbed down from the couch. He picked up his truck and rolled it on the floor. He made a honk sound.
Mia saw that Sam was unhappy. She felt sorry for him. She wanted to make him happy. She had another idea. She decided to trade her doll for the knob.
"Sam, do you want to trade the knob for my doll?" Mia asked. "I will give you my doll and you give me the knob. Then we can both have new toys. It is a fun game."
Sam looked at Mia and felt surprised. He did not expect her to offer her doll. He liked her doll. It was pretty and soft. He thought it was a nice toy. He smiled and nodded.
"Okay, Mia, let's trade the knob for the doll," Sam said. "That sounds like a fun game. Thank you for being my friend."
Mia smiled and nodded. She gave Sam her doll and took the knob. They hugged and said thank you. Then they played with their new toys. They were happy and had fun. They forgot about selling and buying. They learned about trading and sharing.

Tom likes to play with his computer. He likes to see the pictures and hear the sounds. He likes to press the buttons and make things happen. He has a computer in his room, on his desk.
One day, Tom wants to play with his computer after lunch. He runs to his room and climbs on his chair. He looks for the button to turn on his computer. But he cannot find it. He looks on the side, on the back, on the front. He cannot see the button.
He feels sad and angry. He shouts, "Where is the button? I want to play with my computer!"
His mom hears him and comes to his room. She sees Tom looking for the button. She smiles and says, "Tom, the button is not on the computer. It is on the wall. See, there is a cord that goes from the computer to the wall. The cord needs power to make the computer work. The button on the wall gives power to the cord. You need to turn on the button on the wall first, then you can turn on the computer."
Tom looks at the wall and sees the button. He says, "Oh, I see. Thank you, mom." He goes to the wall and turns on the button. He hears a click and sees a light. He goes back to his desk and turns on his computer. He sees the screen turn from black to colorful. He hears the music and the voices. He smiles and says, "Yay, I can play with my computer now!" He starts to play with his computer and has fun. His mom watches him and feels happy. She says, "Have fun, Tom. I love you." She kisses him and leaves his room. Tom says, "I love you too, mom." He plays with his computer until it is time for a nap.

Anna liked to collect rocks. She had many rocks in her room. Some were big, some were small, some were shiny, some were dull. She liked to look at them and feel them in her hands.
One day, she went to the lake with her mom and dad. The lake was big and blue and had many fish and ducks. Anna saw some rocks on the shore. She ran to them and picked them up. They were different from her rocks at home. They were smooth and wet and had colors like the rainbow.
She put them in her bucket and showed them to her mom and dad. They smiled and said they were pretty. Anna wanted to find more rocks. She walked along the shore and looked for them. She saw something shiny in the water. She went closer and saw a big rock. It was very shiny and had many shapes on it. It looked like a star.
Anna was curious. She wanted to touch the rock. She reached out her hand and touched it. It felt cold and hard. She tried to lift it, but it was too heavy. She pulled harder, but it did not move. She wondered what it was and why it was in the lake. It was a mysterious rock.
She heard her mom and dad calling her. They said it was time to go home. Anna looked at the rock and felt sad. She wanted to take it with her. She said goodbye to the rock and told it she would come back. She ran to her mom and dad and showed them her bucket of rocks. They said they were very nice and put them in the car. Anna was happy. She had collected many rocks today. She hoped the mysterious rock would wait for her. She wanted to see it again.

Tom and Mia are friends. They like to play together. One day, they want to create a pizza. They go to the kitchen and find some bread, cheese, sauce and ham. They put the sauce on the bread, then the cheese and ham on top. They are happy.
They put the pizza in the oven and wait. They smell something good. They are hungry. They want to eat the pizza. They open the oven and take out the pizza. It is hot and yummy.
But then, Ben comes in. Ben is rude. He sees the pizza and says, "That is my pizza. Give it to me." He tries to grab the pizza from Tom and Mia. They say, "No, Ben. This is our pizza. We create it. You did not help. Go away."
Ben is angry. He pushes Tom and Mia. He takes the pizza and runs away. He laughs and says, "Ha ha, I have the pizza. You have nothing." He is very rude.
Tom and Mia are sad. They cry. They work hard to create the pizza. They want to share it. But Ben is rude and takes it. They do not like Ben. They say, "Ben is not our friend. He is rude. We do not play with him." They hug each other and go to find something else to play. They hope Ben will learn to be nice.

Tim and Lily went to the zoo with Mom and Dad. They saw many animals, like lions, monkeys, and giraffes. But Tim and Lily liked the penguins best. They watched them swim and slide on the ice.
"Can we feed them?" Lily asked Mom.
"No, sweetie, we can't. They have their own food," Mom said.
Tim saw a man with a bucket of fish. He was wearing a blue coat and a hat. He looked like he worked at the zoo.
"Maybe he can give us some fish to feed the penguins," Tim said. He ran to the man and said, "Hello, sir. Can we have some fish, please?"
The man smiled and said, "Sure, kid. You can have one fish each. But be careful, they might bite."
He offered Tim and Lily a fish from the bucket. Tim and Lily thanked him and walked to the penguin pool. They held the fish in their hands and waved them at the penguins.
The penguins saw the fish and came closer. They made loud noises and flapped their wings. Some of them jumped out of the water and tried to grab the fish.
"Wow, they are hungry!" Lily said.
But one penguin was different. He was smaller and quieter than the others. He stayed in the corner of the pool and looked sad.
"What's wrong with him?" Tim asked.
"I don't know. Maybe he is sick or lonely," Lily said.
She felt sorry for the little penguin. She decided to give him her fish. She walked to the edge of the pool and said, "Here, little penguin. This is for you. I hope you like it."
She threw the fish to the penguin. He looked surprised and happy. He caught the fish in his beak and ate it. He waddled to Lily and rubbed his head against her hand. He made a soft noise.
"Aw, he likes you!" Tim said.
Lily smiled and petted the penguin. He felt warm and soft. She said, "You're welcome, little penguin. You're very cute."
The penguin nodded and smiled. He followed Lily wherever she went. He wanted to be her friend.
But the other penguins were not happy. They were jealous and angry. They wanted more fish. They wanted Lily's attention. They started to chase the little penguin and peck at him. They made loud noises and flapped their wings.
"Hey, stop that!" Tim said. He tried to protect the little penguin. He said, "Leave him alone. He's our friend."
But the penguins did not listen. They kept attacking the little penguin. They made him cry.
Lily was scared and sad. She said, "Mom, Dad, help! The penguins are mean to the little penguin. They hurt him."
Mom and Dad heard Lily's cry. They ran to the penguin pool. They saw the penguins fighting. They saw the little penguin bleeding.
They called the man with the bucket. He came and said, "What's going on here?"
He saw the little penguin and said, "Oh, no. He's the new penguin. He just arrived yesterday. He's not used to the others. They don't like him. They bully him."
He picked up the little penguin and said, "Don't worry, little guy. I'll take you to the vet. He'll make you better."
He thanked Tim and Lily for feeding the little penguin. He said, "You're very kind, kids. You made him happy. He likes you. Maybe you can visit him again when he's well."
He took the little penguin away. Tim and Lily waved goodbye. They hoped the little penguin would be okay.
They hugged Mom and Dad. They said, "We're sorry, Mom and Dad. We didn't mean to cause trouble. We just wanted to feed the penguins."
Mom and Dad hugged them back. They said, "It's okay, Tim and Lily. We know you meant well. You did a good thing. You showed the little penguin some love. You're very brave and sweet."
They kissed Tim and Lily. They said, "We're proud of you, kids. We love you."
They left the zoo. They went home. They had a warm and cozy night. They dreamed of the little penguin. They hoped he would be happy. They hoped he would find some friends. They hoped they would see him again.

Sara and Tom were playing with their toys in the living room. They liked to make up stories with their dolls and cars. Sara had a big doll with long hair and a pink dress. Tom had a small car with four wheels and a horn.
"Let's pretend that my doll is a princess and your car is a dragon," Sara said. "The dragon wants to take the princess to his cave, but she is frightened and wants to escape."
"OK," Tom said. "But the dragon is very strong and fast. He can catch the princess easily."
Sara and Tom moved their toys around the floor, making noises and voices. Sara made her doll run away from Tom's car, but Tom chased her with his car, honking and growling.
"Help, help!" Sara made her doll cry. "The dragon is coming! He wants to lock me in his cave!"
"No one can help you, princess!" Tom made his car say. "You are mine now! I will part you from your friends and family!"
Sara did not like Tom's game. She felt scared and sad for her doll. She wanted to stop playing, but Tom did not listen. He grabbed her doll with his car and tried to pull her hair.
"Stop it, Tom!" Sara shouted. "You are hurting my doll! Give her back to me!"
"No, I won't!" Tom shouted back. "She is my prisoner! You can't have her!"
Sara and Tom started to tug and pull on the doll's hair. They both wanted to have the doll, but they did not want to share. They got angry and loud. They did not notice that their mom was watching them from the kitchen.
"Hey, hey, hey!" their mom said. "What is going on here? Why are you fighting over the doll?"
Sara and Tom stopped and looked at their mom. They felt ashamed and sorry. They realized that they had been mean and rude to each other.
"We were playing a game, mom," Sara said. "But Tom was too rough and scary. He wanted to lock my doll in his cave and part her from me."
"I was just pretending, mom," Tom said. "But Sara did not like my game. She wanted to keep her doll and not let me play with her."
Their mom sighed and shook her head. She walked over to them and took the doll from their hands. She looked at the doll's hair and saw that it was tangled and pulled.
"Look what you did to the doll," she said. "You ruined her hair. How do you think she feels?"
Sara and Tom looked at the doll and felt bad. They saw that they had hurt the doll and each other.
"We are sorry, mom," they said. "We are sorry, doll."
Their mom smiled and hugged them. She gave them the doll back and helped them fix her hair.
"It's OK, my loves," she said. "I know you were just playing, but you have to be careful and kind. You have to respect each other's toys and feelings. You have to share and take turns. And you have to use your words, not your hands, when you have a problem. OK?"
"OK, mom," Sara and Tom said. "We understand. We will do better."
They hugged their mom and thanked her. Then they hugged each other and apologized. They decided to play a different game, one that they both liked and agreed on. They were happy and friendly again. They learned their lesson.

Lily and Tom were eager to see the fire. They heard the big noise and saw the red light in the sky. They ran to the window and looked outside. They saw the fire truck and the firemen. They saw the water and the smoke. They saw the fire.
"Wow!" Lily said. "Look at the fire! It is so big and bright!"
"Can we go outside and see it?" Tom asked. He wanted to get closer to the fire.
"No, no, no!" Mom said. She came to the window and pulled them away. "The fire is very hot and dangerous. You have to stay inside and be safe."
"But why?" Tom questioned. He did not understand why they could not go outside.
"Because the fire can hurt you and burn you. And the smoke can make you cough and sick. And the firemen have to work hard to stop the fire. You have to listen to Mom and stay inside." Mom explained.
Lily and Tom were sad and curious. They wanted to see the fire, but they also wanted to be safe and healthy. They decided to listen to Mom and stay inside. They watched the fire from the window until it was gone. They hoped that no one was hurt by the fire. They thanked the firemen for their work. They learned that fire is not a toy, but a force of nature.

Tim and Kim were twins who liked to play in their room. They had many toys and books and a big mattress to jump on. Sometimes they made a fort with the mattress and the blankets and pretended to be pirates or explorers.
One day, their mom told them she had to go to the store and asked them to be good and not make a mess. She said she would be back soon and left them some snacks and juice. Tim and Kim said okay and waved goodbye.
After mom left, Tim and Kim decided to play with the mattress. They dragged it to the middle of the room and started to jump on it. They had fun bouncing and laughing and making silly faces. But then, Tim had an idea.
"Let's make the mattress more fun," he said. "Let's put some juice on it and make it slippery."
Kim thought that was a bad idea. She said, "No, Tim, that's dangerous. We could fall and hurt ourselves. And we could spoil the mattress and make mom angry."
But Tim did not listen. He grabbed a bottle of juice and poured some on the mattress. He said, "Come on, Kim, don't be a baby. It's just juice. It will dry up."
He jumped on the mattress and slid on the juice. He said, "Whee, this is fun. Try it, Kim."
Kim shook her head. She said, "No, Tim, I don't want to. It's not fun, it's stupid. Stop it, Tim, or I'll tell mom."
But Tim did not stop. He poured more juice on the mattress and jumped and slid. He said, "You're no fun, Kim. You're a boring girl. I'm having a blast."
He did not see that the juice was dripping on the floor and making a big puddle. He did not hear that mom was coming back and opening the door. He did not notice that mom was shocked and angry when she saw the mess.
"Tim, Kim, what have you done?" mom yelled. "You spoiled the mattress and the floor. You made a huge mess. You were very naughty and dangerous. How could you do this?"
Tim and Kim stopped jumping and looked at mom. They felt scared and sorry. They said, "We're sorry, mom. We were just playing. We didn't mean to spoil the mattress."
Mom sighed. She said, "Playing is good, but you have to be careful and respectful. You have to listen to each other and to me. You have to clean up your mess and apologize. And you have to promise me you will never do this again."
Tim and Kim nodded. They said, "We promise, mom. We're sorry, mom. We love you, mom."
Mom hugged them. She said, "I love you too, Tim and Kim. But you have to learn from your mistakes. Now, let's get some towels and clean this up. And then, you have to go to bed early. No more playing with the mattress today."

Sam and Mia were twins who liked to explore new places. One day, they went with their mom and dad to visit a big temple. The temple had many stairs, statues, and paintings. Sam and Mia wanted to see everything, so they ran and rushed from one thing to another.
"Slow down, children," their mom said. "You might get lost or hurt yourself. And be respectful of the temple and the people here."
But Sam and Mia did not listen. They kept rushing and running, until they bumped into an elderly man. The man was wearing a long robe and a hat. He was holding a stick and a book. He looked very angry.
"Hey, watch where you are going!" the man shouted. "You have no manners. This is a sacred place, not a playground. You should be quiet and calm, and learn from the wisdom of the temple."
Sam and Mia felt scared and sorry. They realized they had been rude and careless. They apologized to the man and bowed their heads.
"We are sorry, sir," they said. "We did not mean to bother you. We were just curious and excited. But you are right, we should be respectful and learn from the temple."
The man softened his expression and smiled. He saw that the children were sincere and humble. He decided to forgive them and teach them.
"It is good that you are curious and excited, children," he said. "But you must also be careful and mindful. The temple is a place of peace and harmony, where you can find beauty and wisdom. Come, I will show you some of the treasures of the temple, and tell you some of the stories behind them."
Sam and Mia nodded and followed the man. They walked slowly and quietly, and listened attentively. They saw and learned many new things, and felt happy and grateful. They thanked the man for his kindness and generosity.
